question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 어법상 틀린 것은?
mainText:
Perhaps worse than attempting to get the bad news
out of the way is attempting to soften it or simply not
 <u>address it at all.</u> This “Mum Effect” — a term coined
by psychologists Sidney Rosen and Abraham Tesser in
the early 1970s — happens because people want to
avoid  becoming  the  target  of  <u>others’  negative
emotions.</u> We all have the opportunity to lead change,
yet it often requires  <u>of us the courage to deliver bad
news  to  our  superiors.</u>  We  don’t  want  to  be  the
innocent  messenger  who  falls  before  a  firing  line.
When our survival instincts kick in, they can override
our courage until the truth of a situation gets watered
down. “The Mum Effect and the resulting filtering can
have  <u>devastated effects in a steep hierarchy,” writes
Robert  Sutton,  an  organizational  psychologist.</u>  “What
starts out as bad news becomes happier and happier
as it travels up the ranks ― because after each boss
hears the news from his or her subordinates, he or she
makes it sound a bit less  <u>bad before passing it up
the chain.</u>”
options: ① <u>address it at all.</u>

② <u>others’  negative
emotions.</u>

③ <u>of us the courage to deliver bad
news  to  our  superiors.</u>

④ <u>devastated effects in a steep hierarchy,” writes
Robert  Sutton,  an  organizational  psychologist.</u>

⑤ <u>bad before passing it up
the chain.</u>
explanation: effects를 수식하는 분사로, 파괴적인 결과를 가져오 는 능동관계이므로 현재분사 devastating으로 고쳐야 한다.

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 어법상 틀린 것은?
mainText:
Most parents think that if our child would just “behave,”
we  could  stay  calm  as  parents.  The  truth  is  that
managing  our  own  emotions  and  actions  <u>is what
allows us to feel peaceful as parents.</u> Ultimately we can’t
control our children or the obstacles they will face – but
we can always control our own actions. Parenting isn’t
about what our child does, but about how we respond. In
fact, most of what we call parenting  <u>takes place within
the  parent,  not  between  a  parent  and  child.</u>  When  a
storm brews, a parent’s response will either calm it or
trigger a full-scale tsunami.  <u>Staying calm enough to
respond constructively to all that childish behavior and
the stormy emotions behind it to grow as parent.</u> If we
can use those times  <u>when our buttons get pushed to
reflect,  not  just  react,  we  can  notice  when  we  lose
equilibrium and steer ourselves back on track.</u> This inner
growth is the hardest work there is, but it’s what is able
to let you  <u>become a more peaceful parent, one day at
a time.</u>
options:
① <u>is what
allows us to feel peaceful as parents.</u>

② <u>takes place within
the  parent,  not  between  a  parent  and  child.</u>

③ <u>Staying calm enough to
respond constructively to all that childish behavior and
the stormy emotions behind it to grow as parent.</u>

④ <u>when our buttons get pushed to
reflect,  not  just  react,  we  can  notice  when  we  lose
equilibrium and steer ourselves back on track.</u>

⑤ <u>become a more peaceful parent, one day at
a time.</u>
explanation: '부모로서 성장하기 위해 그 모든 유치한 행동과 그 뒤에 숨겨진 폭풍 같은 감정에 건설적으로 반응할 수 있을 정도로 충분히 침착하라'라는 의미의 명령문이므로, ③ Staying을 Stay 로 고쳐야 한다.

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 어법상 어색한 부분을 포함하고 있 는 것을 모두 고르시오.
mainText:
From the earliest times,  <u>healthcare services have
been  recognized  to  have  two  equal  aspects,  namely
clinical care and public healthcare.</u> In classical Greek
mythology,  the  god  of  medicine,  Asklepios,  had  two
daughters, Hygiea and Panacea.  <u>The former was the
goddess of preventive health and wellness, or hygiene,
and  the  latter  was  the  goddess  of  treatment  and
curing.</u>  In  modern  times,  the  societal  ascendancy  of
medical professionalism has caused treatment of sick
patients  <u>to  overshadow  those  preventive
healthcare services provided the less heroic figures of
sanitary engineers, biologists, and governmental public
health officers.</u> Nevertheless,  <u>the quality of health
that  human  populations  enjoy  is  attributable  less  to
surgical dexterity, innovative pharmaceutical products,
and bioengineered devices than to the availability of
public  sanitation,  sewage  management,  and  services
which control the pollution of the air, drinking water,
urban  noise,  and  food  for  human  consumption.</u> 
<u>The human right to the highest attainable standard of
health  depend  on  public  healthcare  services  no  less
than  on  the  skills  and  equipment  of  doctors  and
hospitals.</u>  
*ascendancy: 우세 **dexterity: 기민함
options:
① <u>healthcare services have
been  recognized  to  have  two  equal  aspects,  namely
clinical care and public healthcare.</u>

② <u>The former was the
goddess of preventive health and wellness, or hygiene,
and  the  latter  was  the  goddess  of  treatment  and
curing.</u>

③ <u>to  overshadow  those  preventive
healthcare services provided the less heroic figures of
sanitary engineers, biologists, and governmental public
health officers.</u>

④ <u>the quality of health
that  human  populations  enjoy  is  attributable  less  to
surgical dexterity, innovative pharmaceutical products,
and bioengineered devices than to the availability of
public  sanitation,  sewage  management,  and  services
which control the pollution of the air, drinking water,
urban  noise,  and  food  for  human  consumption.</u>

⑤ <u>The human right to the highest attainable standard of
health  depend  on  public  healthcare  services  no  less
than  on  the  skills  and  equipment  of  doctors  and
hospitals.</u>
explanation: 덜 영웅적인 인물들에 의해서 제공되는 그러한 예방적 헬스케어 서비스라는 의미의 수동관계이므로 ③번을 provided by로 고쳐야 한다. 또한 'The human right'가 단수 주 어이므로, ⑤번을 'depends'로 고쳐야 한다.

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 어법상 틀린 것은?
mainText:
By noticing the relation between their own actions and
resultant  external  changes,  infants  develop  self‐
efficacy, a sense that they are agents of the perceived
changes. Although infants can notice the effect of their
behavior  on  the  physical  environment,  it  is  in  early
social interactions  <u>that infants most readily perceive
the  consequence  of  their  actions.</u>  People  have
perceptual characteristics that virtually assure  <u>that
infants  will  orient  toward  them.</u>  They  have  visually
contrasting  and  moving  faces.  They  produce  sound,
provide  touch,  and  have  <u>interesting  smells.</u>  In
addition, people engage with infants by exaggerating
their facial expressions and  <u>inflected their voices in
ways  that  infants  find  fascinating.</u>  But  most
importantly,  these  antics  are  responsive  to  infants’
vocalizations, facial expressions, and gestures; people
vary the pace and level of their behavior in response to
infant actions. Consequentially, early social interactions
provide a context  <u>where infants can easily notice the
effect of their behavior.</u>
* inflect: (음성을) 조절하다 ** antics: 익살스러운 행동
options:
① <u>that infants most readily perceive
the  consequence  of  their  actions.</u>

② <u>that
infants  will  orient  toward  them.</u>
③ <u>interesting  smells.</u>

④ <u>inflected their voices in
ways  that  infants  find  fascinating.</u>

⑤ <u>where infants can easily notice the
effect of their behavior.</u>
explanation: 전치사 by의 목적어로 쓰인 동명사 exaggerating와 병렬을 이루고 있으므로, ④ inflected를 inflecting으로 고쳐야 한다.

each of us focuses on one specific skill,  <u>lead to a

It  is  not  the  peasant’s  goal  to  produce  the  highest
possible  time‐averaged  crop  yield,  averaged  over
many  years.  If  your  time‐averaged  yield  is
marvelously high as a result of the combination of nine
great years and one year of crop failure, you will still
starve  to  death  <u>in  that  one  year  of  crop  failure
before you can look back to congratulate yourself on
your  great  time‐averaged  yield.</u>  Instead,  the

That’s  why  field  scattering  may  make  sense.  If  you

low yield.</u> But if you have many different fields, varying
independently  of  each  other,  then  in  any  given  year
some of your fields will produce well even when your
other fields are producing  <u>poor.</u>

④ <u>in which your one field has a

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 ①~⑤ 중, 어법상 옳은 것은?
mainText:
There  are  several  reasons  why  support  may  not  be
effective. One possible reason is  <u>that receiving help
could  a  blow to  self-esteem.</u>  A  recent  study  by
Christopher Burke and Jessica Goren at Lehigh University
examined this possibility. According to the threat to self-
esteem model, help can be perceived as supportive and
loving, or it can  <u>be seen as threatening if what help is
interpreted as  implying  incompetence.</u>  According  to
Burke and Goren, support is especially likely to be seen
as threatening if it is in an area that is self-relevant or
self-defining – that  is,  <u>in  an  area  which  your  own
success  and  achievement  are  especially  important.</u>
Receiving help with a self-relevant task can make you
feel bad about yourself, and  <u>this can be undermined
the potential positive effects of the help.</u> For example, if
your self-concept rests, in part, on your great cooking
ability, it may be a blow to your ego  <u>when a friend
helps you prepare a meal for guests because it suggests
that you’re not the master chef you thought you were.</u>
options:
① <u>that receiving help
could  a  blow to  self-esteem.</u>

② <u>be seen as threatening if what help is
interpreted as  implying  incompetence.</u>

③ <u>in  an  area  which  your  own
success  and  achievement  are  especially  important.</u>

④ <u>this can be undermined
the potential positive effects of the help.</u>

⑤ <u>when a friend
helps you prepare a meal for guests because it suggests
that you’re not the master chef you thought you were.</u>
explanation: ① 동명사 주어인 'receiving'의 본동사가 필요하므 로, 'could <be> a blow', ② what → 지시 형용사 'that', ③ which → 'where' + 완전한 절, ④ 'the potential positive effects'라는 목적어가 있으므로, 'be undermined'를 능동의 형 태인 'undermine'로 고쳐야 한다.

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 어법상 틀린 것은?
mainText:
Psychologist Christopher Bryan finds that when we shift
our emphasis from behavior to character, people evaluate
choices differently. His team was able to cut cheating in
half: instead of "Please don't cheat," they changed the
appeal to "Please don't be a cheater." When you're urged
not to cheat, you can do it and still see an ethical person
in the mirror. But when you're told not   <u>to cheat, the
act casts a shadow; immorality is tied to your identity,</u> <u>make the behavior much less attractive.</u> Cheating is
an isolated action that  <u>gets evaluated with the logic of
consequence: Can I get away with it?</u>  <u>Being a cheater
evokes  a  sense  of  self,  triggering  the  logic  of
appropriateness: What kind of person am I, and who do I
want to be?</u> In light of this evidence, Bryan suggests that
we  should  embrace  nouns  more  thoughtfully.  "Don't
Drink  and  Drive"  could  be  rephrased  as:  "Don't  Be  a
Drunk Driver." The same thinking can  <u>be applied to
originality.</u>  When  a  child  draws  a  picture,  instead  of
calling  the  artwork  creative,  we  can  say  "You  are
creative."
options:
① <u>to cheat, the
act casts a shadow; immorality is tied to your identity,</u>
② <u>make the behavior much less attractive.</u>

③ <u>gets evaluated with the logic of
consequence: Can I get away with it?</u>

④ <u>Being a cheater
evokes  a  sense  of  self,  triggering  the  logic  of
appropriateness: What kind of person am I, and who do I
want to be?</u>

⑤ <u>be applied to
originality.</u>
explanation: 앞 부분(immorality ~ identity)이 동사를 포함한 완전한 절의 형태로 추가적인 동사가 올 수 없으며, 앞 부분의 절 의 내용을 주체로 하는 분사구문의 형태가 적절하며 목적어가 이 어지는 능동의 형태이므로 ② make를 making으로 고쳐야 한다.

mainText:
One benefit of reasons and arguments  <u>is that they can
foster humility.</u> If two people disagree without arguing,
all they do is  <u>yell at each other.</u> No progress is made.
Both still think that they are right. In contrast, if both
sides  give  arguments  that  articulate  reasons  for  their
positions,  then  new  possibilities  open  up.  One  of  the
arguments gets  <u>refuted - that is, it is shown to fail.</u> In
that  case,  the  person  who  depended  on  the  refuted
argument learns  <u>that he needs to change his view.</u>
That is one way to achieve humility - on one side at
least.  Another  possibility  is  that  neither  argument  is
refuted. Both have a degree of reason on their side. Even
if neither person  <u>involving is convinced by the other's
argument, both can still come to appreciate the opposing
view.</u>  They  also  realize  that,  even  if  they  have  some
truth, they do not have the whole truth. They can gain
humility when they recognize and appreciate the reasons
against their own view.
options:
① <u>is that they can
foster humility.</u>
② <u>yell at each other.</u>
③ <u>refuted - that is, it is shown to fail.</u>
④ <u>that he needs to change his view.</u>

⑤ <u>involving is convinced by the other's
argument, both can still come to appreciate the opposing
view.</u>
explanation: 주어인 neither person involved와 수동관계이므 로 involved로 고쳐야 한다. 즉, 앞의 명사 person을 수식하는 형 태로 '주격 관계대명사 + be동사 (who is)'가 생략된 구조이므로 볼 수 있다.

mainText:
Psychologist  Christopher  Bryan  finds  that  when  we
shift our emphasis from behavior to character, people
evaluate choices differently. His team was able to cut
cheating in half: instead of “Please don’t cheat,” they
changed  the  appeal  to  “Please  don’t  be  a  cheater.”
When you’re urged  <u>not to cheat, you can do it and
still  see  an  ethical  person  in  the  mirror.</u>  But  when
you’re told not to be a cheater, the act casts a shadow;
immorality  is  <u>tied  to  your  identity,  making  the
behavior much less attractive.</u> Cheating is an isolated
action  that  gets  evaluated  with  the  logic  of
consequence: Can I get away with it? Being a cheater
evokes  a  sense  of  self,  <u>triggering  the  logic  of
appropriateness: What kind of person am I, and who
do  I  want  to  be?</u>  In  light  of  this  evidence,  Bryan
suggests  that  we  embrace  nouns  more  thoughtfully.
“Don’t Drink and Drive” could  <u>rephrase as: “Don’t
Be a Drunk Driver.</u>” The same thinking can be applied
to originality. When a child draws a picture, instead of
calling the artwork  <u>creative, we can say “You are
creative.</u>”
options:
① <u>not to cheat, you can do it and
still  see  an  ethical  person  in  the  mirror.</u>

② <u>tied  to  your  identity,  making  the
behavior much less attractive.</u>

③ <u>triggering  the  logic  of
appropriateness: What kind of person am I, and who
do  I  want  to  be?</u>

④ <u>rephrase as: “Don’t
Be a Drunk Driver.</u>

⑤ <u>creative, we can say “You are
creative.</u>
explanation: [기출 응용] “Don’t Drink and Drive”라는 문장이 다시 고쳐서 말 되는 수동이므로 be rephrased로 고쳐야 한다.

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 어법상 틀린 것은?
mainText:
Perhaps worse than attempting to get the bad news
out of the way is  <u>attempting to soften it or simply
not  address  it  at  all.</u>  This  “Mum  Effect”  —  a  term
coined  by  psychologists  Sidney  Rosen  and  Abraham
Tesser  in  the  early  1970s  —  happens  because 
<u>people want to avoid becoming the target of others’
negative emotions.</u> We all have the opportunity to lead
change,  yet  it  often  requires  of  us  the  courage  to
deliver bad news to our superiors. We don’t want to be
the innocent messenger who falls before a firing line.
When our survival instincts kick in, they can override
our  courage  <u>until  the  truth  of  a  situation  gets
watered  down.</u>  “The  Mum  Effect  and  the  resulting
filtering  can  have  devastating  effects  in  a  steep
hierarchy,”  writes  Robert  Sutton,  an  organizational
psychologist. “ <u>What start out as bad news becomes
happier  and  happier  as  it  travels  up  the  ranks  ―
because after each boss hears the news from his or
her subordinates,</u> <u>he or she makes it sound a bit
less bad before passing it up the chain.</u>”
options:

not  address  it  at  all.</u>

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 어법상 틀린 것은?
mainText:
Most  parents  think  that  if  our  child  would  just
“behave,” we could stay calm as parents. The truth is
that managing our own emotions and actions  <u>to be
what allows us to feel peaceful as parents.</u> Ultimately
we can’t control our children or the obstacles they will
face  ―but  we  can  always  control  our  own  actions.
Parenting isn’t about what our child does, but about 
<u>how  we  respond.</u>  In  fact,  most  of  what  we  call
parenting  doesn’t  take  place  between  a  parent  and
child  but  within  the  parent.  When  a  storm  brews,  a
parent’s  response  will  either  calm  <u>it  or  trigger  a
full‐scale  tsunami.</u>  Staying  calm  enough  to  respond
constructively to all that childish behavior ― and the
stormy emotions behind it ― <u>requires that we grow,
too.</u> If we can use those times when our buttons get
pushed to reflect, not just react, we can notice when
we  lose  equilibrium  and  steer  <u>ourselves  back  on
track.</u> This inner growth is the hardest work there is,
but it’s what enables you to become a more peaceful
parent, one day at a time.
options:
① <u>to be
what allows us to feel peaceful as parents.</u>
② <u>how  we  respond.</u>

③ <u>it  or  trigger  a
full‐scale  tsunami.</u>

④ <u>requires that we grow,
too.</u>

⑤ <u>ourselves  back  on
track.</u>
explanation: 'managing~ actions'의 동명사구 주어의 동사자리 이고 주어를 3인칭 단수 취급하므로, ① to be를 is로 고쳐야 한 다.

question: 다음 글의 밑줄 친 부분 중, 어법상 틀린 것은?
mainText:
If  DNA  were  the  only  thing  that  <u>counted,  there
would  be  no  particular  reason  to  build  meaningful
social programs to pour good experiences into children
and  protect  them  from  bad  experiences.</u>  But  brains
require the right kind of environment if they  <u>are to
correctly develop.</u> When the first draft of the Human
Genome Project came to completion at the turn of the
millennium,  one  of  the  great  surprises  was  that
humans have only about twenty thousand genes. This
number came as a surprise to biologists:  <u>giving the
complexity  of  the  brain  and  the  body,  it  had  been
assumed that hundreds of thousands of genes would
be required.</u> So how does the massively complicated
brain,  with  its  eighty‐six  billion  neurons,  get 
<u>made  from  such  a  small  recipe  book?</u>  The  answer
relies  on  a  clever  strategy  implemented  by  the
genome:  build  <u>incompletely  and  let  world
experience refine.</u>
options:
① <u>counted,  there
would  be  no  particular  reason  to  build  meaningful
social programs to pour good experiences into children
and  protect  them  from  bad  experiences.</u>

② <u>are to
correctly develop.</u>

③ <u>giving the
complexity  of  the  brain  and  the  body,  it  had  been
assumed that hundreds of thousands of genes would
be required.</u>
④ <u>made  from  such  a  small  recipe  book?</u>

⑤ <u>incompletely  and  let  world
experience refine.</u>
